title: Tip-off leads to huge abalone bust
text:
Thanks to a tip-off, Table View police officers arrested a man in possession of shucked abalone worth approximately R1.5 million.

According to the tip-off, the man was travelling in a white BMW X5 on the West Coast Road (R27), direction Table View.

Table View police spokesperson Capt Adriana Chandler says shortly before 11:00 on Thursday 3 October, officers saw the vehicle turning from the R27 onto Blaauwberg Road and followed the vehicle.

“In Porterfield Road in Table View, the driver was instructed to pull to the side of the road and the officers approached the vehicle with caution. They noticed large plastic bags on the front and back seat of the vehicle and asked the driver to exit the car. Officers also asked permission to search the vehicle and the man obliged,” she says.

Inside the boot, the officers found more bags. The bags were filled with shucked abalone.

“The driver was asked for a permit to transport the abalone, but he failed to produce such document and was arrested,” she says.

The vehicle with the abalone still inside, was taken to Table View police station where the officers contacted the officials from the department of agriculture, forestry and fisheries who counted the abalone. It amounted to 1 973 units of shucked abalone, with an estimated street value of R1.5 million.

“The officers then decided to go to the home of the suspect in Table View. Permission was granted to search the house and the officers found dried fish and lobster at the home, which were also handed to sea fisheries inspectors,” she says.

The 35-year-old man appeared in the Cape Town magistrate’s court on charges of being in possession of abalone under the Living Marine Resources Act.
